children.subject: 189 creates the foundation for ML. Going deeper into why/how things work creates a stronger base. You build on top by taking more ML courses. Also, not applicable in industry? You'd be surprised.
Alright. I’ll consider taking it then. Thanks.

+1 would recommend CS 189/289A for a strong foundation.  This foundation is required to get in-depth with ML, be it industry or research (i.e. go beyond simple application of out-of-the-box ML tools).  You said "just seems more of a math class" -- surprise, surprise, ML fundamentals are linear algebra and probability.

history.content: Machine learning is in essence just linear algebra and probability, so 189 isn't "just a math class." So yes, if you're interested in machine learning, then you'll need the fundamentals from 189. (if you're gonna try to do anything outside of out-of-the-box pre-trained models/tutorials, you'll need the fundamentals to know what you're doing)

Lewin's maxim --- "There's nothing as practical as a good theory" --- applies.

It is easy for students to lose sight of the fact that fields will evolve. Some of what is the research frontier now will become mainstream in the future, and then even some of that will become obsolete. Your education has to last you decades and the reality is that although you have experienced your whole life so far as being filled with people trying to educate you properly (from when you are a baby till now), this will change very dramatically when you are in the workforce. In the workforce in the face of a constant stream of new graduates and recently experienced people that can be hired quite affordably, there is little incentive for companies to invest in the fundamental development/education of their existing workforce, especially if that workforce is mobile. Remember, your compensation (and hence cost to your employer) is determined by your *outside option.* True understanding raises your outside option while being trained to interpolate newer techniques within your employer's context is only locally valuable if you lack fundamentals --- thereby not raising your outside option. 

That's why it is important to understand the fundamentals like EECS126 and 127. That's why 189 builds on them to ground you in ML from a fundamental point of view. The ML of today is not going to be the ML of tomorrow. But if you understand the fundamentals, you will be able to keep up in the future. Fundamentals are never enough by themselves. But they are like a permanent power-up for every other trick that you learn in the future.

children.subject: Thank you Professor Sahai! Your response was great and has really allowed me to see in better clarity the extent of my cs education here.

history.content:
Hi should I take this class even if I don’t plan on being in the research field at all? This class just seems more of a math class and some of its actual machine learning topics seem old and not up to date. I have knowledge of some ml topics through self study but not to an extent where I can fully write a proof on something of course. The class itself seems interesting but I am not sure if it is applicable for a career path in industry (business/cs). Thanks! 


Edit: by applicable I don’t mean the actual ml topics but the depth to which 189covers these   topics.
history.subject: Usefulness of 189
